intro: Gomphocarpus grandiflorus var. tomentosus, commonly known as the woolly milkweed, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its hairy, gray-green foliage and produces clusters of small, yellow-orange flowers. The plant belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is known for its milky sap, which is toxic to many animals. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in grasslands and along roadsides. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
